channel.title: Mentoring
channel.description:
Hey guys.. I am horrific at HTML and don't even know the basics. Yes, I will be looking at the beginner tutorials and everything I can find that will help me out. Everybody learns new things better using their own type of method. Some people are hands on, some people can just jump right into whatever they are learning, and others just need mentoring. I am one that likes hands on experience and mentoring. I am looking for someone who would be willing to answer my stupid questions and help me progress through my learning of HTML. Hopefully whoever decides to help me out, we will become good friends and have babies.. no not that but we would become friends. Anyways, if anyone is willing to help me out so if I have a question not answered by a tutorial you will be there, I would really appreciate and be excited for us to start. PM or comment if you are interested.
Please don't complain about this thread. I tried to write enough explanations of why I'm doing it to minimalism complaints.
Thank you!

item.title: Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

I taught myself basic HTML/CSS by just doing inspect element on various web pages to see how they worked. I used W3Schools for quick reference, didn’t have any problems with it.

Read full topic

item.title: Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @RevengePK RevengePK
item.description:
@RevengePK wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:16, topic:542607”][quote author=RevengePK link=topic=661480.msg4421790#msg4421790 date=1398801066]

This is what I did to get where I’m at:

I started off with W3Schools to get the jist

http://www.w3fools.com/

I read something about W3Schools suggesting the use of WYSIWYG editors.

From W3Schools’s own footer…

We do not warrant the correctness of [W3Schools] content. The risk from using it lies entirely with the user.

I have him learning the jist from codeacademy. As of now hes completed the HTML course and has a solid understanding and is moving smoothly through CSS. Then we’re going to move on to layouts, techniques, practice, and the like.

[/quote]It’s where I started, not where I base my beliefs.

codeschool is gr8 though. Interactive, and less reference-like. Throws you into figuring out potential real life problems.[/quote]

That is exactly why I had him start there. Kind of like a game.

Read full topic

item.title: Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:4, topic:542607”]http://codebabes.com

You will never forget web design and you’ll become very pro at it.
There is also no tutorial site that is free and codebabes is most likely the best site on the internet for html.[/quote]

There are plenty of tutorial websites that provide free tutorials? From my knowledge at least.

@OP: Try your hardest with doing it on your own, if you’re having a problem with something along the way, just post a thread here asking for some help, also indicate the problem that you’re having. People here are usually willing to help. If you have a quick question, I can say I’d be glad to answer, I’m usually on Skype throughout the day (for work) just send me a message: aj.cordio

Read full topic

item.title: Mentoring
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

This is what I did to get where I’m at:

I started off with W3Schools to get the jist, to get familiar with what may be available. Then I would download free templates that I thought were interesting, and would either try to mimic the look, or I’d just read through it and understand what I didn’t know yet. Now I just fux with bootstrap because I don’t give a crap, ain’t got no time for that, omg I can rap.

Read full topic
